snippet: The European Court of Justice said search engines like Google should allow users to be “forgotten” after a certain time by erasing links to web pages unless there are “particular reasons” not to.
abstract: European Court of Justice says that people have the right to influence what the world can learn about them through online searches; burden of court's ruling will largely fall on Google; ruling rejects long-established notions about free flow of information on the Internet and underlines power of search companies to retrieve controversial information while simultaneously placing sharp limits on their ability to do so.

byline.contributor: James Kanter, Mark Scott and Raphael Minder contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: The European Court of Justice said search engines like Google should allow users to be “forgotten” after a certain time by erasing links to web pages unless there are “particular reasons” not to.

headline.main: European Court Lets Users Erase Records on Web
headline.print_headline: European Court Lets Users Erase Records on Web
